result.execSummary:
The defendant Jeremiah Michael Bloedorn was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Resisting or Obstructing an Officer, a class A misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 946.41(1).
  • Possess Amphetamine/LSD/Psilocin, an unclassified misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 961.41(3g)(d).

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

All available enforcement actions will be used to collect the debt.

Defendant Jeremiah Michael Bloedorn in court with attorney Leonie Dolch.  Defendant Jeremiah Michael Bloedorn in custody.  Kevin R. Calkins appeared for the State of Wisconsin. Cts 1 & 2 sentence after probation revocation.  Both parties recv'd and reviewed revocation summary.  Ready to proceed.  State gives recommendation and statement of defendants history. 9 mos. jail x 2, concurrent to each other but consecutive to any other.  J.C. drafted a statement and Atty. Dolch will read that.  Atty. Dolch doesn't object to 9 mos. on each but concurrent to any other sentence and if not concurrent then sentence 3 mos. jail concurrent to each but consecutive to any other.  Defendant makes statement.  If Court makes concurrent there would be 201 days credit.  Court imposes sentence.
